conditions.name: Anxiety & Stress
conditions.description: A nervous system condition characterized by persistent feelings of worry, nervousness, or unease, often accompanied by physical symptoms such as muscle tension, rapid heartbeat, and gastrointestinal distress. Anxiety ranges from occasional situational stress to chronic generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), which involves difficulty controlling worry on most days for at least six months. The stress response activates the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis and sympathetic nervous system, and herbal approaches aim to modulate these pathways through nervine, anxiolytic, and adaptogenic actions.
symptoms: sleep disturbances (difficulty falling or staying asleep)
approaches: Anxiolytic nervines (lavender, passionflower) for acute anxiety relief — lavender extract (Lavela/Silexan) has clinical evidence comparable to low-dose benzodiazepines
Calming nervines (chamomile, lemon balm) as daily teas or extracts to reduce baseline tension and promote relaxation
Adaptogens (ashwagandha, holy basil) for long-term HPA axis support and stress resilience, taken consistently over weeks
Sedative nervines (valerian, passionflower) at bedtime when anxiety disrupts sleep
Kava for moderate situational anxiety — effective short-term but limited to 4-8 weeks due to hepatotoxicity risk; avoid with alcohol or liver conditions
Aromatherapy with lavender essential oil (inhalation or topical dilution) for immediate calming effect
Combination formulas pairing an adaptogen for chronic support with a nervine for acute episodes (e.g., ashwagandha daily + chamomile tea as needed)
lifestyle: Regular physical exercise — moderate to vigorous activity for 2+ hours per week reduces anxiety symptoms; mindful movement (yoga, tai chi, qigong) is particularly effective
Consistent sleep schedule with 7-9 hours nightly; practice sleep hygiene (dark room, no screens before bed, consistent wake time)
Daily meditation or mindfulness practice, even 5-10 minutes — guided imagery, intentional breathing, and progressive muscle relaxation all show benefit
Limit or eliminate caffeine, as chronic use is linked to increased anxiety; switch to herbal teas or decaffeinated options
Reduce or avoid alcohol and nicotine, both of which alter brain chemistry and worsen anxiety over time
Nutrient-dense diet rich in lean protein, complex carbohydrates, fruits, vegetables, and omega-3 fatty acids to support neurotransmitter production
Maintain social connections — isolation worsens anxiety; regular contact with supportive friends, family, or support groups builds resilience
Spend time in nature — green spaces and natural environments have documented cortisol-lowering effects
conditions.whenToSeek: Seek professional help if anxiety persists most days for six weeks or more, significantly interferes with work, relationships, or daily activities, causes repeated panic attacks, involves avoidance of normal situations, is accompanied by depression or substance use, or includes thoughts of self-harm. Physical symptoms like chest pain, severe shortness of breath, or dizziness warrant immediate medical evaluation to rule out cardiac or thyroid conditions.

conditions.name: Insomnia & Sleep Issues
conditions.description: Difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or waking too early. Can be occasional or chronic, often related to stress, anxiety, or poor sleep habits.
approaches: Sedative herbs taken 30-60 minutes before bed
Nervine teas to wind down in evening
Lavender aromatherapy or pillow sachets
Consistent evening herbal ritual
conditions.whenToSeek: If insomnia persists for more than a few weeks, if accompanied by daytime impairment, or if you suspect sleep apnea

conditions.name: Indigestion & Upset Stomach
conditions.description: Discomfort in the upper abdomen including bloating, gas, nausea, or a feeling of fullness. Often related to eating too quickly, rich foods, or stress.
approaches: Carminative herbs to relieve gas and bloating
Bitter herbs before meals to stimulate digestion
Soothing teas after meals
Ginger for nausea
conditions.whenToSeek: If symptoms persist, are severe, include vomiting blood, unexplained weight loss, or difficulty swallowing

conditions.name: Common Cold
conditions.description: Viral upper respiratory infection causing congestion, sore throat, runny nose, and general malaise. Typically lasts 7-10 days.
approaches: Immune-supporting herbs at first sign of symptoms
Diaphoretic teas to support fever
Expectorant herbs for congestion
Throat-soothing preparations
conditions.whenToSeek: If fever is high or prolonged, symptoms worsen after 10 days, difficulty breathing, or symptoms of secondary infection

conditions.name: Influenza (Flu)
conditions.description: More severe viral respiratory illness than a cold, with sudden onset of high fever, body aches, fatigue, and respiratory symptoms.
approaches: Elderberry to reduce duration and severity
Diaphoretic herbs to support fever response
Immune-stimulating herbs
Soothing preparations for symptoms
lifestyle: Allow fever to work (unless dangerously high)
conditions.whenToSeek: Difficulty breathing, persistent chest pain, confusion, severe vomiting, high-risk groups (elderly, pregnant, immunocompromised)

conditions.name: Headache & Tension
conditions.description: Pain or discomfort in the head, often related to tension, stress, dehydration, or eye strain. Tension headaches are most common.
approaches: Peppermint oil applied to temples (diluted)
Lavender aromatherapy
Anti-inflammatory herbs for pain
Nervine herbs if tension-related
conditions.whenToSeek: Sudden severe headache, headache with fever and stiff neck, headache after head injury, changes in vision or speech

conditions.name: Skin Irritation & Minor Wounds
conditions.description: Minor skin issues including rashes, irritation, minor cuts, scrapes, burns, and insect bites.
approaches: Vulnerary herbs to promote healing
Anti-inflammatory herbs to reduce irritation
Antimicrobial herbs to prevent infection
Demulcent herbs to soothe and protect
conditions.whenToSeek: Signs of infection (increasing redness, pus, fever), deep wounds, burns larger than 3 inches, wounds that won't stop bleeding

conditions.name: Nausea & Motion Sickness
conditions.description: Feeling of sickness with an inclination to vomit. Can be caused by motion, pregnancy, digestive upset, or other factors.
approaches: Ginger in any form - tea, capsules, crystallized, or fresh
Peppermint tea or aromatherapy
Small sips rather than large amounts
Aromatherapy with calming scents
conditions.whenToSeek: Persistent vomiting, blood in vomit, signs of dehydration, severe abdominal pain, head injury

conditions.name: Inflammation & Pain
conditions.description: Body's response to injury or irritation, causing redness, swelling, heat, and pain. Can be acute or chronic.
approaches: Anti-inflammatory herbs taken consistently
Topical applications for localized pain
Combining multiple anti-inflammatory herbs
Addressing root cause alongside symptom relief
conditions.whenToSeek: Severe pain, inability to move joint, signs of infection, inflammation without known cause

conditions.name: Weak Immunity
conditions.description: Tendency to catch illnesses frequently, slow recovery, or general feeling of being run down. Often related to stress, poor diet, or lack of sleep.
approaches: Adaptogenic herbs for long-term resilience
Immune-modulating herbs taken consistently
Elderberry during cold/flu season
Deep immune tonics for chronic weakness
conditions.whenToSeek: Frequent severe infections, infections that don't respond to treatment, unexplained weight loss or fatigue

conditions.name: Joint Pain & Arthritis
conditions.description: Discomfort, aching, or soreness in one or more joints, most commonly caused by osteoarthritis (cartilage degradation), rheumatoid arthritis (autoimmune synovial inflammation), or gout (crystal deposition). Joint pain originates from activation of nociceptors in the joint capsule, periosteum, ligaments, and synovium — not the cartilage itself, which lacks nerve endings. Pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1, TNF-α) drive a cycle of inflammation, degradative enzyme production, and progressive joint destruction. Herbal approaches target these inflammatory cascades through COX/LOX inhibition, antioxidant support, and connective tissue nourishment, offering a complementary strategy alongside conventional care.
symptoms: persistent aching or soreness in one or more joints
joint stiffness, especially upon waking or after inactivity
swelling or visible puffiness around the joint
warmth or redness over the affected area
reduced range of motion or difficulty bending/straightening
crepitus (grinding, clicking, or popping sensation during movement)
weakness or instability in the affected joint
pain that worsens with activity or weather changes
fatigue or general malaise accompanying chronic joint inflammation
difficulty with daily tasks (gripping, climbing stairs, walking)
disturbed sleep due to nighttime joint pain
muscle tension or compensatory soreness around affected joints
approaches: Anti-inflammatory herbs (turmeric/curcumin, boswellia) for chronic joint inflammation — curcumin meta-analysis shows efficacy comparable to NSAIDs for OA pain; combine with black pepper (piperine) to increase bioavailability by up to 2000%

Natural salicylates (willow bark, meadowsweet) for acute pain relief — contain salicin which converts to salicylic acid; gentler on the stomach than synthetic aspirin but avoid with aspirin allergy or blood-thinning medications
Warming circulatory herbs (ginger, cayenne) for stiff, cold joints — ginger clinical trials show reduced knee OA pain; use internally as tea or decoction, or externally as warming compresses

Connective tissue support (rosehip, nettle) for long-term cartilage maintenance — rosehip meta-analysis of 3 trials showed one-third pain reduction in 300 OA patients; nettle provides anti-inflammatory silicic acid and minerals
Topical analgesics (cayenne/capsaicin, arnica, comfrey) for localized joint relief — capsaicin cream depletes substance P at nerve endings; apply 3-4 times daily for cumulative effect over 1-2 weeks
Combination formulas (boswellia + ginger + glucosamine) for synergistic effect — 6-month trial showed significant WOMAC score improvement for moderate knee OA without safety concerns

Traditional system approaches (Ayurvedic: turmeric, fenugreek, shallaki for Vata imbalance; TCM: acupuncture for Bi syndrome blockage) as complementary therapy — both systems emphasize addressing root imbalance alongside symptomatic relief
lifestyle: Low-impact exercise for 2+ hours per week — walking, swimming, cycling, or tai chi to maintain joint mobility and strengthen supporting muscles; tai chi specifically shown to improve OA pain, balance, and flexibility

Anti-inflammatory diet following Mediterranean pattern — fatty fish 2x/week for omega-3s, colorful fruits and vegetables, whole grains; eliminate or reduce sugar and processed foods which trigger pro-inflammatory cytokine release
Maintain healthy body weight — each pound of excess weight adds 4 pounds of pressure on knee joints; fat tissue also produces inflammatory adipokines that damage joints beyond mechanical stress
Quality sleep of 7-9 hours nightly — poor sleep amplifies pain sensitivity and systemic inflammation; use supportive pillows or positioning aids for affected joints
Quit smoking — tobacco triggers systemic inflammation, slows tissue healing, and reduces blood flow to joint structures

Daily stress management through meditation, yoga, or gentle movement — stress hormones cortisol and adrenaline amplify inflammatory pathways; NIH studies confirm mindfulness meditation reduces arthritis pain perception

Alternate heat and cold therapy — apply heat (warm compresses, baths) for stiffness and chronic ache; cold packs for acute swelling and inflammation; 15-20 minutes per application, several times daily as needed
conditions.whenToSeek: Seek medical evaluation if joint pain persists for more than two weeks, limits daily activities, or does not improve with rest and over-the-counter remedies. Urgent red flags include sudden severe swelling in a single joint with warmth and fever (possible septic arthritis — a medical emergency that can destroy joint structures within hours), unexplained weight loss alongside joint symptoms, visible joint deformity, or inability to bear weight. Joint pain accompanied by skin rash, eye inflammation, or mouth sores may indicate systemic autoimmune conditions requiring prompt diagnosis.
